body:
I cannot see where it is used, any more info? I am aware of JCTools, and it is likely we use it to detect the max direct memory limits...
Anyway, VarHandle could be a decent replacement, but it is unlikely 4.1. will benefit about it

It's probably from here: https://github.com/netty/netty/blob/378ab6ab4202058aa1d3c6a14a946cd6fbfac996/common/src/main/java/io/netty/util/internal/PlatformDependent0.java#L257-L261

You can either ignore the warning, since Netty is auto-detecting availability, or you can disable it explicitly with `-Dio.netty.noUnsafe=true` (note, this property have have a different name in the shaded version).

You can also control this behavior with the `--sun-misc-unsafe-memory-access` argument:

```
    --sun-misc-unsafe-memory-access=<value>
                      allow or deny usage of unsupported API sun.misc.Unsafe
                      <value> is one of "allow", "warn", "debug", or "deny".
                      The default value is "warn".
```
Aside: you should avoid shading and shaded dependencies whenever possible.

@franz1981 this is all the information I see in the logs. If you could tell me how to get more info, I'll gladly do that. 

Even if 4.1 doesn't benefit from it, perhaps it would still be a good idea to fix it in a future release to stay in line with the direction the JDK is taking.

> [@chrisvest](https://github.com/chrisvest) my fear about ignoring the warning is that this method might be removed altogether in a future Java release, making it much more of a blocker than just a warning.

Netty will be fine because we auto-detect availability, which is the code that is causing the warning.

> Regarding, providing those additional flags, since those will need to be done by the end-application owners and not library maintainers (in this case grpc-java), it is not a nice developer experience.

These are JVM settings. Libraries cannot control this.

> Perhaps, it would be better if the default was changed to not use unsafe - to make it compatible with the direction the Java platform is headed in.

That will be the plan, I think, just like we did for reflective access.

issue.title: Disable sun.misc.Unsafe by default on Java 24+

repository.name: netty
repository.description: Netty project - an event-driven asynchronous network application framework

issue.body:
### Warning

Without access to `sun.misc.Unsafe`, Netty is unable to eagerly free direct `ByteBuffer` instances, and instead has to rely on the garbage collector and reference processing.

This delays the freeing of unused memory, and can cause greatly increase the memory usage of busy systems.

To revert the Netty behavior and permit it to eagerly free memory, apply one of the following settings to your JVM command line:

* `--sun-misc-unsafe-memory-access=allow` (preferred)
* `-Dio.netty.noUnsafe=false` (may or may not work for shaded libraries)

Alternatively, upgrade to Netty 4.2 where we are able to apply a long-term work-around.

See https://github.com/netty/netty/wiki/Java-24-and-sun.misc.Unsafe for more information.

---

Motivation:
Java 24 has started to print warnings when `sub.misc.Unsafe` is used to access memory. See JEP 498: https://openjdk.org/jeps/498

People tend to be sensitive to new warnings and errors printed by the JVM, so we should avoid enabling `Unsafe` by default on Java 24 onwards.

Modification:
Effectively change the default value of the `io.netty.noUnsafe` system property for Java 24 onwards, but in a way where we can tell if it was explicitly set to a given value or if it follows the default.

Any sort of explicit settings, be it `-Dio.netty.noUnsafe=false` or `--sun-misc-unsafe-memory-access=allow`, will continue to work as before.

Manually verified that the changes work as intended on Java 24.

Result:
No more warnings printed to the console on Java 24+.

Fixes https://github.com/netty/netty/issues/14942

issue.title: JDK +24 and io_uring

repository.name: netty
repository.description: Netty project - an event-driven asynchronous network application framework

issue.body: Due to https://github.com/netty/netty/issues/14942 it is likely that io_uring won't work anymore (since it is an avid Unsafe user) - it is not something we can fix in Netty 4.1, but maybe in Netty 4.2 we can leverage `VarHandle` or users won't be able to use such.

issue.title: Disable sun.misc.Unsafe by default on Java 24+ (#14943)

repository.name: netty
repository.description: Netty project - an event-driven asynchronous network application framework

issue.body:
Motivation:
Java 24 has started to print warnings when `sub.misc.Unsafe` is used to access memory. See JEP 498: https://openjdk.org/jeps/498

People tend to be sensitive to new warnings and errors printed by the JVM, so we should avoid enabling `Unsafe` by default on Java 24 onwards.

Modification:
Effectively change the default value of the `io.netty.noUnsafe` system property for Java 24 onwards, but in a way where we can tell if it was explicitly set to a given value or if it follows the default.

Any sort of explicit settings, be it `-Dio.netty.noUnsafe=false` or `--sun-misc-unsafe-memory-access=allow`, will continue to work as before.

Manually verified that the changes work as intended on Java 24.

Result:
No more warnings printed to the console on Java 24+.

Fixes https://github.com/netty/netty/issues/14942

body: Is it possible to back-patch this into 4.1.x? @normanmaurer
Trying to eliminate the warnings in Apache `protonj2` which has yet to bump to 4.2.0.

issue.title: Fix init order of PlatformDependent0 fields

repository.name: netty
repository.description: Netty project - an event-driven asynchronous network application framework

issue.body:
Motivation:

After #14975, `EXPLICIT_NO_UNSAFE_CAUSE` has a dependency to `JAVA_VERSION`, which is initialized after it. When `explicitNoUnsafeCause0()` tries to set `io.netty.noUnsafe` to true by default on Java 24, it fails, because `javaVersion()` always returns 0 at that point.

Also, `isAndroid0()` is called twice, once in `javaVersion0()` and once to initialize `IS_ANDROID`. This is not a bug or a performance issue, but it does have a visible side-effect when debug logging is enabled.

Modification:

The declaration of `EXPLICIT_NO_UNSAFE_CAUSE` is moved after `JAVA_VERSION`, ensuring `javaVersion()` returns the correct version when `explicitNoUnsafeCause0()` calls it.

`IS_ANDROID` is also moved before `JAVA_VERSION`, such that the `isAndroid0()` method is called only once.

Result:

Fixes #14942 correctly
